Changed the Record Delimiter character used by Cloud Data Warehouse to extract data in CSV format, in order to avoid conflicts with carriage return characters appearing in certain free comment fields in SCD
CustomerApplyNote: Changed the Record Delimiter character used by Cloud Data Warehouse to extract data in CSV format, in order to avoid conflicts with carriage return characters appearing in certain free comment fields in SCD.  When applying this patch, it is necessary to update the Snowflake Schema File Format used to read data extracted from SCD into the Snowflake Schema.  To do that, rerun the Create/Fix Schema script available through the Schema Connections window in Data Warehouse Manager.  Alternatively, run this command in all relevant Snowflake schemas: ALTER FILE FORMAT <schema_name>_FILE_FORMAT SET RECORD_DELIMITER = '\x1C';

For the UpSessions that also are 3-tier user sessions we now adjust the inactivity timeout when needed to mitigate the risk of exhausting available AplSessions.
If the 105 service reaches 90% of the available APLSessions in the AplSessionPool the inactivity timeout on user sessions is restricted from 1 hour to 5 mins
If the 105 service after the restriction has been applied; again reaches 80% or less of the available APLSessions in the AplSessionPool the inactivity timeout restriction on user sessions gets lifted to default again

Changes to the inactivity timeout of user sessions is logged to AppInsights at Information level

The Performance Measurement used FX rates from t-2 for translating time series reallocation payments and inception/termination date market values to LC when changing reporting currency.  The LC values are used for calculating TWR local and Local return and the purpose of these are to omit all FX effects by using FX rates from t-1. The Performance Measurement was therefore introducing FX effects in TWR local and Local return when using FX rates from t-2. The error has been corrected by ensuring that FX rates from t-1 are used for LC values.

Avoid ‘bufSlavesSet’ in the Group Currency Accounting code of the position fetching flow. The so-called slave buffer can be updated directly. This avoids having to set all slave buffers on the basis of their respective slave containers in the main buffer. An issue with temporary out-of-sync match data in the slave container of the main buffer and the slave buffer itself is avoided in position fetching.

For many year (minimum 15years) Carried Amortised Cost QC/PC values have been set to zero for taxable corporate actions in the special accounting values. However Carried Amortised Cost Currency PC and Carried Amortised Cost Currency Correction PC where not zeroed. 
This had no practical influence on the accounting bookings and positions involved in the corporate action. But it has created unnecessary noise when validating changed results in internal batch job group results.
To avoid future noise Carried Amortised Cost Currency PC and Carried Amortised Cost Currency Correction PC will also be zeroed.

Performance Calculation has a check box named 'Decompose TWR into income and capital'. An income cash flow will be calculated if this is selected and the income cash flow can be affected by synthetic payments. Synthetic payments originating from Position Netting XIM and Position Netting CDS transactions was, however, not split into income and capital and thus these transactions would never impact the income cash flow. Fixed calculation of I-spread for forward started bonds/swaps and/or bonds/swaps which are interest only or have non-bullet redemption structure. For bonds/swaps priced with zero coupon yield curve, swap rate on bond/swap maturity is calculated from zero coupon yield curve using syntethic swap which has the same payment dates and coupon terms as original one, but bullet redemption. For forward started bonds/swaps, swap rate is calculated on bond/swap effective(start) date.

A simple data provider for Logical Form Tests (LFTs) is created. It respects the LFT architecture and enables searching for transaction data via the window ‘View Transactions’. It also enables the creation of new portfolios by copying existing ones. This complements and reduces the need for restricted exclusive access to AIDE_MASTER_AZ to persist specific test data for an LFT. It is possible to create new test data programmatically for LFTs by creating new transactions based on new portfolios in many but not necessarily all cases.

What are the problems/motivations for the changes?
When making partial reallocations for positions with a high number of tax lots then a rounding check could end up putting a too big correction on single tax lot. By too big it is meant above 2 times the smallest unit of the currency e.g. 0.02 for EUR or USD). This would cause the golden equation to fail for the corrected tax lot.
Secondly reallocation values for Initial Premium and Discount values could become incorrect.
Thirdly if a tax lot had an incorrect value for Balance Initial Premium and Discount and was fully sold a check would be made which could cause Balance Initial Premium and Discount not to go to zero on the tax lot.

What is the proposed solution?
First the rounding check has been improved so a single lot will not get more than 2 times the smallest unit of the currency. Then later golden equation checks on individual tax lot level will be able to ensure that the golden equation holds per tax lot. As a consequence the rounding check for reallocations will affect more tax lots.
Secondly a correction has been made to ensure correct reallocation values for Initial Premium and Discount values.
Thirdly a correction has been made so a check on Initial Premium and Discount values is not executed for fully sold tax lots.
